Mtrs. Carpet in the Building No. B-4, in Satellite Classic, situated on the land bearing CTS No. 261 & 263 of Village Bandivali, Taluka Andheri, District Mumbai Suburban District and located at Caves Road, Jogeshwari (East), Mumbai-400060, for the consideration mentioned therein, hereinafter referred to as “THE SAID FLAT” (more particularly described in the SCHEDULE hereunder written). AND WHEREAS, the MR. VITHAL V. KAMAT, became the absolute owner of the said Flat. MR. VITHAL V. KAMAT is the Donor herein and DR. (MRS). JAYANTI MANMOHAN KAMAT is the Donee herein. AND WHEREAS the Donor is holding all Rights, Title, interest and claim in respect of the said Flat. AND WHEREAS the Donor herein is the Member and share holder of the Satellite Classic Co-operative Housing Society Ltd., (the Said Society) and holding 5 Shares of Rs.50/- each bearing Share Certificate No. 097, under Distinctive Nos. 0481 to 0485 (both inclusive) hereinafter referred to as the 'SAID SHARES' and paying the maintenance charges in respect of the said Flat to the said Society. AND WHEREAS Donee herein, who is the daughter of the Donor and having love and affection towards each other. AND WHEREAS Donor has great love and affection towards the Donee, the Donor has freely and willingly desire to transfer his all Shares, rights, title and interest in the said Flat to the Donee by way of Gift without any monetary consideration and by way of love and affection, which the Donee is ready to accept and the Donor and Donee herein have decided to reduce the terms and conditions of this Deed of Gift in writing as under: NOW THIS GIFT DEED WITNESSETH AS UNDER: That the Donor do hereby give his Shares, rights, title and interest in respect of said Flat No. 001, on the Ground Floor, area admeasuring 38.57 Sq. Mtrs. Carpet in the Building No. B-4, in Satellite Classic CHSL., Caves Road, Jogeshwari (East), Mumbai -400060 by way of Gift to the Donee herein and absolutely assign, transfer along with all rights, shares, appurtenant thereto, without any monetary consideration in favour of and unto the Donee and the Donee hold and possess the same as absolute owner in all respects. The possession Share, rights, title and interest in respect of the said Flat will be handed over to the Donee and the same will be accepted by the Donee. It is agreed by and between the parties that, the Donee shall be entitled to use and occupy the said Flat as owner forever without any let, hindrance, denial, demands, interruption or eviction or objection from the Donor or any person claiming lawfully or equitably under or in trust for the Donor from the date of execution hereof. That the Donor has desire, decide and agree to transfer the said Flat to the Donee herein together with all documents/papers thereof. Henceforth, the Donee shall be the absolute owner of the said Flat and said Shares along with and She, Donee shall be at full liberty /power to deal with or dispose of the said Flat to any one as She may like being member of the Said Society as per the provisions of the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960 and rules made there under. The Donor hereby declares that he has full right and authority to transfer, assign and convey his all shares, rights, title and interest together with membership and/or occupancy rights in respect of the said Flat to the Donee and he has neither created any charges, claim, lien or encumbrances on or upon or against his share in respect said Flat nor mortgaged the same to anybody whomsoever and the Donor shall indemnify that the Donee and the said Society to remove, defend all such claims, objections, encumbrances, whatsoever at her own cost and shall not allow the Donee and the Society to suffer on this account. That the Donor has desire, decide and declare to relinquish /release/wave all his Share, right, title, interest and claim of whatsoever nature over the said Flat in favour of the Donee herein with an undertaking that neither he himself nor any of the heirs, representatives, legal heirs, nominees shall claim over the Share in respect said Flat directly or indirectly in person or representative from the Donee herein in future. That the Donor doth hereby for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators covenant with the said Donee that notwithstanding any act, deed, matter or things of whatsoever by the Donor or by any person or persons lawfully or equitably claiming by, from, through, under or in trust for his made done, committed, omitted or knowingly or willingly suffered to the contrary he, the Donor now within in himself good right, full power and absolute authority to grant, convey and assure his all Share in respect said Flat hereby agreed to gift, assign, transfer, grant, convey or assure or intend to do so to be unto and to the use of the said Donee in the manner aforesaid. That the Donor has NO OBJECTION of whatsoever for transfer of his right, title, interest and share in respect the said Flat /Share Certificate along with the necessary papers and other documents, for transfer of necessary records of the said Flat to or in the name of Donee by the concerned/competent authorities. The Donor further declares that he will obtain the No Objection and consent from the legal heirs and legal representatives of the Donor for transferring his Share in respect of the said Flat, its Share Certificate, Society Membership, etc. in the name of the Donee. That the all share, rights, title and interest of the Donor herein in respect of said Flat will be gifted, assigned and transferred by way of Gift, without any monetary consideration, however, required Stamp Duty has been paid on this Gift Deed. Stamp Duty Details: Market Value of Property: ? 95,00,000 Stamp Duty Paid: ? 4,75,000 (5%) Registration Fee: ? 95,000 (1%) E-Stamp Certificate No.: MH-ESD-2025-9834761, dated 13/10/2025 SCHEDULE ABOVE REFERRED TO All shares, rights, title, interest and claim of the said Flat No. 001 on the Ground Floor area admeasuring 38.57 Sq. Mtrs. Carpet in the Building No. B-4, Satellite Classic Co-operative Housing Society Ltd., Caves Road, Jogeshwari (East), Mumbai 400060, and situated on land bearing CTS No. 261 & 263 of Village Bandivali, Taluka Andheri, Mumbai Suburban District and Share Certificate No. 097 and Distinctive Numbers 0481 to 0485. The said Building was constructed in the year 2001. IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties hereto have hereunto set and subscribed their respective hands/signature on the day, month and year first hereinabove written. SIGNED AND DELIVERED BY the Within named “THE DONOR”: MR. VITHAL V. KAMAT In the presence of: Name: G. Sundar Name: L. Revathi SIGNED AND DELIVERED BY the Within named “THE DONEE”: DR. (MRS) JAYANTI MANMOHAN KAMAT In the presence of: Name: A. Prakash Name: M. Iyer
summary: This Deed of Gift, executed on October 15, 2025, in Mumbai, documents the non-monetary transfer of a residential flat from Mr. Vithal V. Kamat (Donor) to his daughter, Dr. (Mrs) Jayanti Manmohan Kamat (Donee), driven purely by natural love and affection. The gifted property is Flat No. 001, Ground Floor, Building No. B-4, Satellite Classic CHSL, Jogeshwari (East), Mumbai, covering a carpet area of 38.57 Sq. Mtrs., including the Donor's membership rights and 5 shares (Share Certificate No. 097) in the Co-operative Housing Society. The Donor absolutely relinquishes all rights, title, interest, and claim over the said flat and covenants that the property is free from all encumbrances, promising to indemnify the Donee against any future claims. By accepting the gift, the Donee becomes the absolute owner with full liberty to deal with or dispose of the flat. The document is registered after paying substantial stamp duty of ?4,75,000 (5%) and a registration fee of ?95,000 (1%) on the market value of ?95,00,000. The Donor further undertakes to obtain No Objection and consent from his legal heirs for the transfer of the Society Membership and flat rights into the Donee's name.

text: A F F I D A V I T I, Rohit S. Naik Son/Daughter of Suresh P. Naik, Businessman, major in age (state here profession/occupation), resident of (state here Village, Taluka and State in which you are residing) H. No. 123, Azad Lane, Mapusa, Bardez, Goa, do hereby solemnly affirm and state on oath as under: That I appeared for the Third Semester Examination of the Bachelor of Commerce Programme of Goa University in the year 2023 under Seat No. GU/BCOM/45678. That my Statement of Marks/Passing Certificate/Degree Certificate of the said examination/s held in November 2023 is/are misplaced/lost/stolen and cannot be traced despite my best efforts for the reason/s mentioned below: a) The original documents were kept in a folder which was misplaced during my relocation to a new residence. b) A thorough search has been conducted at my old and new residences, but the documents have not been found. That I have filed a Missing Article Report/F.I.R. at the nearest Police Station at Mapusa Police Station on 15th December 2023 under Missing Report/F.I.R. No. MR-112/2023. That I am swearing this affidavit in order to produce the same before the Controller of Examinations, Goa University, for obtaining duplicate Statement of Marks/Passing Certificate/Convocation Degree. That in the event the lost document/s is/are found, I hereby agree and undertake to surrender the same to the University. V E R I F I C A T I O N I, (full name Rohit Suresh Naik), on solemn affirmation and oath state that all the facts stated in paragraphs 1 to 5 are correct to the best of my knowledge and belief and nothing is false or concealed. The contents being true I swear this affidavit. Solemnly affirmed at Mapusa on 20th day of December 2023. Rohit S. Naik Name of the Deponent Before me. [Signature and Seal of Notary/Oath Commissioner] Notary Public/Oath Commissioner Mapusa, Goa
summary: This document is a formal Affidavit (a sworn written statement) executed by Mr. Rohit S. Naik in Mapusa, Goa, on December 20, 2023. Deponent's Identity: Deponent: Mr. Rohit S. Naik, Son of Suresh P. Naik, a Businessman. Residence: H. No. 123, Azad Lane, Mapusa, Bardez, Goa. Statement of Loss and Purpose: Examination Details: The Deponent appeared for the Third Semester Examination of the Bachelor of Commerce Programme of Goa University in November 2023, under Seat No. GU/BCOM/45678. Documents Lost: The original Statement of Marks/Passing Certificate/Degree Certificate for the said examination(s) is/are misplaced/lost/stolen. Reason for Loss: The original documents were kept in a folder and were misplaced during relocation to a new residence, and a thorough search has been unsuccessful. Official Report: A Missing Article Report/F.I.R. was filed at the Mapusa Police Station on December 15, 2023, under Report No. MR-112/2023. Purpose: The affidavit is being sworn to be produced before the Controller of Examinations, Goa University, for the purpose of obtaining duplicate Statement of Marks/Passing Certificate/Convocation Degree. Undertaking: The Deponent formally agrees and undertakes to surrender the lost document(s) to the University immediately in the event they are found later. Verification: The Deponent verifies on oath that all facts stated in the affidavit are correct to the best of his knowledge and belief and nothing has been falsely stated or concealed.

text: DEBT COMPROMISE AGREEMENT This Deed of Compromise is entered into between Mr. Rajesh Kumar, S/o. Late R. Narayan, residing at H.No. 12-4/7, Banjara Hills, Hyderabad – 500034, Telangana (hereinafter called the Creditor) AND Mr. Arvind Rao, S/o. P. Srinivas Rao, residing at Flat No. 204, Green Residency Apartments, Madhapur, Hyderabad – 500081, Telangana (hereinafter called the Debtor) on this 28th day of October, 2025. WHEREAS The Debtor has taken a loan of Rs. 3,00,000/- (Rupees Three Lakhs Only) from the Creditor on 15th March 2023, with an interest rate of 10% per annum. The aforesaid loan was payable by the Debtor on or before 15th March 2024. AND WHEREAS, the Debtor has failed to repay the loan and interest thereon, and the Creditor, in order to recover his loan, has agreed to accept a total amount of Rs. 2,50,000/- (Rupees Two Lakhs Fifty Thousand Only) in full satisfaction of the said loan and interest thereon. NOW THIS DEED OF COMPROMISE WITNESSES AS FOLLOWS: That the Debtor has paid an amount of Rs. 2,50,000/- (Rupees Two Lakhs Fifty Thousand Only) to the Creditor on 28th October 2025, the receipt of which the Creditor hereby acknowledges. That the Creditor has accepted the aforesaid amount in complete satisfaction of the amount of loan and interest thereon. That the Creditor now has no claim against the Debtor in respect of the aforesaid loan. That the Debtor is hereby discharged from his liability of repayment of the said loan and interest thereon. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, both the Creditor and Debtor have signed this compromise on the day, month, and year first above written. For Debtor: (Signed) Mr. Arvind Rao Flat No. 204, Green Residency Apartments, Madhapur, Hyderabad – 500081, Telangana. For Creditor: (Signed) Mr. Rajesh Kumar H.No. 12-4/7, Banjara Hills, Hyderabad – 500034, Telangana. WITNESSES Witness 1: Name: Mr. Suresh Babu Address: H.No. 10-2/19, Jubilee Hills, Hyderabad – 500033, Telangana. Signature: ______________________ Witness 2: Name: Ms. Neha Reddy Address: Plot No. 45, Kavuri Hills, Madhapur, Hyderabad – 500081, Telangana. Signature: ______________________
summary: This Debt Compromise Agreement, executed on October 28, 2025, formally settles a past loan dispute between Mr. Rajesh Kumar (Creditor) and Mr. Arvind Rao (Debtor). The original debt stemmed from a loan of ?3,00,000/- (Three Lakhs) taken by the Debtor on March 15, 2023, which carried a 10% per annum interest rate and was due for full repayment by March 15, 2024. Since the Debtor failed to repay the full amount, the Creditor agreed to a compromise to fully recover his funds. The core of this deed is the agreement by the Creditor to accept a total amount of ?2,50,000/- (Two Lakhs Fifty Thousand Only) in full and final satisfaction of both the original principal loan and the accrued interest. The Debtor confirms the payment of this compromise amount to the Creditor on the same day the deed was signed, October 28, 2025, and the Creditor explicitly acknowledges receipt of this payment. By accepting this lesser amount, the Creditor formally states he has no further claim against the Debtor regarding this loan. Consequently, the Debtor is legally discharged from all liability for the repayment of the said loan and its interest.

text: EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT This EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT (Hereinafter, the "Agreement") is entered into on this 25th day of October, 2025 ("Effective Date") BY AND BETWEEN FinWise Capital Private Limited, a private limited company incorporated under the Companies Act, 2013, having CIN U65990DL2017PTC280000 with its registered office at 4th Floor, Connaught Tower, New Delhi - 110001 (hereinafter referred to as the "Company" or "Employer", which expression shall, unless repugnant to the meaning or context hereof, be deemed to mean and include all permitted successors and assigns) AND Ms. Aditi Nanda, daughter of Mr. Ravi Nanda, aged about 48 years, with permanent account number ASDPK7890Y, and residing at E-45, Vasant Kunj, New Delhi - 110070 (hereinafter referred to as the "Employee", which expression shall, unless repugnant to the meaning or context hereof, be deemed to mean and include all permitted successors and assigns). The Company and the Employee shall hereinafter be individually referred to as "Party" and collectively referred to as "Parties". NON-JUDICIAL STAMP PAPER DETAILS (Required for Admissibility) State: Delhi (National Capital Territory of Delhi) Stamp Duty Paid: INR 100/- (Rupees One Hundred Only) Unique Document ID (UDID): IN-DL-05-432109-2025 Date of Purchase: 24/10/2025 WHEREAS: A. The Company is a Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) engaged in the business of Retail and Corporate Lending and Financial Services ("Business"). B. The Company wishes to appoint the Employee to a high-level strategic role due to her extensive experience in the financial sector. NOW, THEREFORE, IN CONSIDERATION OF THE MUTUAL COVENANTS AND AGREEMENTS CONTAINED HEREIN, THE PARTIES AGREE AS FOLLOWS: 1. POSITION AND DUTIES 1.1 The Company hereby appoints Ms. Aditi Nanda as a Permanent Full-Time Employee in the capacity of Chief Strategy Officer (CSO), reporting directly to the Managing Director. 1.2 The Employee shall be responsible for developing long-term corporate strategy, identifying new business opportunities, and overseeing strategic partnerships, as further detailed in Annexure A (Key Responsibilities). 1.3 The Employee's primary place of employment shall be the Company's registered office in New Delhi. 2. TERM OF EMPLOYMENT 2.1 The employment shall commence from the Effective Date and is for an indefinite term until terminated in accordance with the provisions of Clause 5. 3. PROBATIONARY PERIOD 3.1 No formal probationary period is applicable for this senior executive role; however, the initial One Hundred and Twenty (120) days shall serve as an extended review period for performance evaluation by the Board. 4. REMUNERATION AND COMPENSATION 4.1 The Employee shall be paid an annual Cost to Company (CTC) of INR 75,00,000/- (Rupees Seventy-Five Lakh Only), structured as per the details in Annexure B (Compensation Statement). 4.2 Compensation includes eligibility for a discretionary annual bonus up to 30% of Basic Salary and participation in the Company's Executive Stock Option Plan (ESOP), subject to vesting schedules. 5. TERMINATION AND NOTICE 5.1 Termination by Either Party (Post-Review): This Agreement may be terminated by either Party by giving Ninety (90) days' prior written notice. 5.2 The Company retains the right to place the Employee on Garden Leave for the entire notice period, during which the Employee shall not be required to report to work but shall remain bound by the terms of this Agreement, including Confidentiality and Non-Compete clauses. 5.3 Change in Control: In the event of a change in control or merger of the Company, and if the Employee's role is eliminated or substantially altered, the Employee shall be entitled to a severance payment equivalent to six months of her last drawn basic salary. 6. NON-COMPETE AND NON-SOLICIT 6.1 The Employee agrees that, during the term of employment and for a period of Two (2) years following termination, she shall not, within the Northern India region (Delhi NCR, Haryana, Punjab, UP), engage in any business, profession, or employment that is competitive with the Company's business. 6.2 The Employee further agrees not to solicit or hire any employees or clients of the Company for a period of Two (2) years post-termination. 7. GOVERNING LAW AND JURISDICTION 7.1 This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of India. 7.2 Subject to the Company's option to invoke arbitration, the appropriate courts in New Delhi shall have exclusive jurisdiction in relation to any matter arising out of this Agreement. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties have executed this Agreement effective as of the date and year first written above. For FinWise Capital Private Limited (Signature of Authorized Signatory) Name: Mr. Arjun Bansal Designation: Managing Director For Employee (Signature) Name: Aditi Nanda Date: 25th October, 2025 [COMPANY SEAL AFFIXED HERE]
summary: This employment agreement, executed on October 25, 2025, establishes Ms. Aditi Nanda as the Chief Strategy Officer (CSO), a permanent, indefinite-term executive position at FinWise Capital Private Limited in New Delhi. Her primary responsibilities are long-term corporate strategy, and the role is subject to an initial 120-day performance review by the Board, as no formal probation applies. Ms. Nanda's annual remuneration (CTC) is INR 75,00,000/- (Seventy-Five Lakh). Critically, her compensation includes high-value incentives: eligibility for a discretionary annual bonus up to 30% of her Basic Salary and participation in the Company's Executive Stock Option Plan (ESOP). Due to the strategic nature of the CSO role, the agreement includes stringent termination and protection clauses. Normal termination requires Ninety (90) days' written notice from either party, and the Company reserves the right to enforce Garden Leave during this period. For executive protection, a severance payment equivalent to six months of last drawn basic salary is triggered if her position is eliminated following a merger or change in control. Most notably, the contract includes powerful post-termination restrictions: a two-year Non-Compete clause binding her across the Northern India region, and a two-year Non-Solicit clause preventing her from targeting the Company's employees or clients. The agreement is governed by the laws of India, with exclusive jurisdiction resting with the courts in New Delhi.

text: Kerala High Court Commissioner Of Customs vs Om Prakash Khatri on 1 March, 2019 Author: Ashok Menon Bench: K.Vinod Chandran, Ashok Menon IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM PRESENT THE HONOURABLE MR.JUSTICE K.VINOD CHANDRAN & THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE ASHOK MENON FRIDAY ,THE 01ST DAY OF MARCH 2019 / 10TH PHALGUNA, 1940 Cus.Appeal.No. 44 of 2018 AGAINST THE ORDER/JUDGMENT IN O.NO. 21786/2018 of CUSTOMS,EXCISE&SERVICE TAX APP.TRIBUNAL,BANGALORE DATED 19-11-2018 APPELLANT/S: COMMISSIONER OF CUSTOMS CUSTOMS HOUSE, COCHIN-682 009, KERALA BY ADV. SRI.THOMAS MATHEW NELLIMOOTTIL, SC RESPONDENT/S: OM PRAKASH KHATRI DIRECTOR, PANNA GOLD IMPEX LTD, 259, JOHRI MANSION, KALBADEVI ROAD, MUMBAI, MAHARASHTRA, PIN-400002 BY ADV. B.R.TRIPATHI THIS CUSTOMS APPEAL HAVING BEEN FINALLY HEARD ON 31.01.2019, ALONG WITH Cus.Appeal.45/2018, Cus.Appeal.46/2018, Cus.Appeal. 47/2018, THE COURT ON 01.03.2019 DELIVERED THE FOLLOWING: JUDGMENT Ashok Menon, J. The Commissioner of Customs, Cochin is before us in appeals aggrieved by the common final order dated 19.11.2018 passed by the Customs, Excise and Service Tax Appellate Tribunal, South Zonal Bench, Bangalore. 2. The facts in brief are thus: On 04.02.2014, two persons named Surendra Singh and Dhiraj Kumar Devasi alleged to be the employees of M/s Panna Gold Impex Ltd., Mumbai, were intercepted by the officers of Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) at Vyttila in Ernakulam; from whose possession were seized gold bars and pieces weighing 4430.730 gms., valued at Rs.1,54,28,372/- and gold ornaments weighing 5536.200 gms. valued at Rs.1,32,78,898/-. That apart, Rs.42,000/- in cash, alleged to be sale proceeds of contraband gold, was also recovered. The confession statements of the apprehended persons revealed involvement of one Om Prakash Khatri, Director of M/s Panna Gold Impex Ltd. Show cause notices were issued to the aforesaid three persons and the company, and after adjudication, the Joint Commissioner as per Annexure A order dated 05.05.2015 ordered absolute confiscation of the gold bars and jewellery under Section 111(a), (d) and (m) read with Section 120(1) of the Customs Act, 1962 (for short "the Act") and also imposed a penalty of Rs.20 lakhs on Om Prakash Khatri and Rs.10 lakhs on M/s Panna Gold Impex Ltd. under Section 114AA of the Act. The Adjudicating Authority also imposed a penalty of Rs.5 lakhs each on the aforementioned three persons as well as the Company under Section 112 of the Act. The currency was however ordered to be released. 3. The appeals filed before the Commissioner was disposed of vide a common order at Annexure B dated 08.10.2015 modifying the order of the Adjudicating Authority by quashing the confiscation of gold ornaments. The remaining part of the order was sustained. The parties again filed a second appeal before the Tribunal, which vide common impugned order allowed the appeal and set aside the adjudicatory order altogether. 4. The Revenue is aggrieved and hence the appeal, raising the following substantial questions of law, as re-framed by us: i) Was the Tribunal justified in finding that the Department has failed to establish that the seized gold were smuggled goods ? ii) Was the Tribunal justified in quashing the entire order of confiscation ? 5. We heard Sri.Thomas Mathew Nellimoottil, Senior Standing Counsel for the Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs appearing for the appellant and Sri.B.R.Tripathi, learned Counsel appearing for the respondents. 6. The Tribunal has, in the impugned order, found that the burden on the Department, to prove that the gold bars and jewellery seized from the two persons apprehended at Vyttila were smuggled gold; was not discharged. It is pointed out that under Section 123 of the Act, the burden was entirely on the Department to prove that the seized gold was smuggled. It is observed that the gold bars were not of standard size, shape or weight and that there were no markings on it. The ornaments were of 91.6% purity and therefore, cannot be assumed to have been imported; which finding we immediately notice was irrelevant insofar as the first appellate authority having released the ornaments. It is also observed that the two persons apprehended were not coming out of any Airport or Seaport, nor were they crossing any international border so as to warrant action under Section 110 of the Customs Act. It is also observed that the Adjudicating Authority and the first appellate authority came to a wrong conclusion relying on the statements of the two salesmen, which was subsequently retracted. 7. Reliance was placed on the decision of the Hon'ble Supreme Court in Collector of Customs, Madras v. D.Bhoormall, 1983 (13) ELT 1546 (SC) and in Collector of Customs (Preveventive) v. Shri Ganesh Enterprises, 2006 (199) ELT 208 (Bom) by the Tribunal to hold that the Department had the burden to prove that the contraband gold had entered the Country illegally and were smuggled. The Tribunal also found fault with the Department for not having examined the twelve persons from whom the respondents had been purchasing gold for the purpose of making ornaments. It is also pointed out that no customs duty has been demanded by the Department from the persons apprehended and there was absolutely no material on the basis of which the Department could have reasonably believed that the goods were smuggled, and therefore, the adjudicating as well as appellate authority's orders were quashed. 8. It is seen that the statements of the two salesmen of the Company were recorded under Section 108 of the Act by the DRI. Wherein, they had stated that they collected gold bars and pieces smuggled into India from Kerala and took the same to Mumbai to be handed over to Om Prakash Khatri, who is one of the Directors of M/s Panna Gold Impex Ltd. It is stated by them that an associate of Om Prakash Khatri at Thiruvananthapruam handed over the gold to them. They also admitted having collected gold from Kerala on earlier occasions for being handed over to Khatri. Ornaments were made out of smuggled gold and sold at a very competitive price. The salesmen revealed that they did not travel by flights for the reason that there was security checking and customs checking at the Airport. 5 kgs. of gold ornaments were given to them to be sold in Kerala, without any document or bill. They also admitted that Khatri had cautioned about the possibility of being intercepted by the Police or the Customs, as the ornaments were made out of smuggled gold. They reached Thiruvananthapuram and met a Keralite, described as a fat and dark person, who handed over the gold bars and pieces. It is also stated by them that the markings in the gold had been removed so as to conceal the identity of the smuggled gold and that the gold was also cut into small pieces and melted. They came to Ernakulam by bus and were intending to sell the ornaments and jewellery in and around Ernakulam as also take back the smuggled gold. But they were intercepted while alighting from a bus at Vyttila, and apprehended by the DRI officials, resulting in the contraband gold being seized. 9. Summons were issued to Khatri and on 06.02.2014, the representative of the Company handed over certain documents, including copies of gold ornaments stock register, refined gold register; along with a covering letter purportedly that of Khatri, but not signed by him, which expressed his inability to appear in person before the DRI. Another summons was issued to him on 07.02.2014, to which also he did not respond. Thereafter, he filed an application for anticipatory bail before the Sessions Court, Ernakulam, which got dismissed. He thereafter approached this Court, and the application was disposed of with a direction asking him to surrender before the DRI on 12.03.2014, to produce all documents and also to co- operate with the investigation. 10. Follow up investigation was also conducted by the DRI at Mumbai and the search revealed that the premises of M/s Panna Gold had another company by name "Om Jewellers", operating in the premises, of which Khatri was the Proprietor. 3790 gms. of gold was seized, but later released, since it was not connected with the seizure at Ernakulam. 11. Khatri's statements were recorded by the DRI on 12.03.2014, 24.03.2014 and 25.03.2014. He also produced certain documents. He was thereafter arrested on 25.03.2014 and produced before the Addl. CJM (Economic Offences), Ernakulam. The Adjudicating Authority found that there was no document to prove the legitimacy of the gold recovered from the two salesmen of M/s Panna Gold Impex Ltd. and in the statements given by them under Section 108 they admitted that the gold handed over to them was smuggled gold and the ornaments seized were made of such smuggled gold. No reliable documentary proof was also produced by the company to prove that they had purchased the gold legally, and therefore, the Adjudicatory Authority ordered confiscation of gold bars and ornaments and also imposed the penalty as stated above. In first appeal, the ornaments were ordered to be released, but the confiscation of gold bars and pieces confirmed. 12. Coming to the finding of the Tribunal regarding the burden of proof, it would be necessary to examine the scope of Section 123 of the Act, which deals with burden of proof in certain cases. Section 123(2) in particular, is pertinent, which reads thus: "123. Burden of proof in certain cases.- (1) When any goods to which this section applies are seized under this Act in the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, the burden of proving that they are not smuggled goods shall be- (a)in a case where the seizure is from the possession of any person,- (i)on the person from whose possession the goods were seized, and (ii)..... (b).......... (2) This section shall apply to gold and manufactures thereof, watches and any other class or good which the Central Government may by notification in the Official Gazette, specify." From a reading of the section, it is explicit that, when any goods to which the Section applies are seized under the Act under the reasonable belief that they were smuggled goods, the burden of proof as to they were not smuggled goods, shall be on the person from whose possession the goods were seized. As far as gold and watches are concerned, the Section applies directly, and regarding other goods, the Central Government may by notification in the official gazette specify. Hence, the finding of the Tribunal that the burden is on the Department to prove that the gold was smuggled, cannot be accepted. The Tribunal has relied on the decision on D.Bhoormall (supra) to justify that the burden is on the Department. A reading of paragraph 34 of the judgment would be pertinent, where, it is stated that it would be enough, if the Department furnishes prima facie proof of the goods being smuggled stock. A reading of Section 123 also require only a reasonable belief as far as gold is concerned, that it was smuggled. The gold was recovered from the possession of the two individuals intercepted by the DRI, who were not able to give a satisfactory explanation to upset the reasonable belief entertained by the DRI officials who recovered huge quantity of unmarked gold from the persons intercepted. In fact the statements made by the intercepted individuals further fortified the belief entertained by the officials. The statement of the carriers of the gold under Section 108 of the Act, can be safely relied upon by the Department to proceed against them. The decision in Shri Ganesh Enterprises (supra) relied on by the Tribunal is not applicable to the case, because the said decision deals with confiscation of non-notified goods and not gold or other notified goods. 13. The learned Counsel for the Department relies on the decision in Labhchand Dhanpat Singh Jain v. State of Maharashtra, AIR 1975 SC 182, wherein the Hon'ble Supreme held as follows: "9. xx xx xx The appellant admitted, in his statement under Section 108 of the Act that H transporting of these pieces of gold was an offence. If the gold had been legally imported before 1948 it could not be an offence to carry it. The appellant had not proved who Pannalal, the person who was alleged by him to have given him the gold to carry, was. Atleast, the burden of proving an innocent receipt of gold lay upon the appellant under Section 106 Evidence Act. The totality of facts proved was enough, in our opinion, to raise a presumption under Section 114 Evidence Act that the gold had been illegally imported into the country so as to be covered by Section 111(d) of the Act. The appellant had not offered any other reasonable explanation of the manner in which it was being carried." 14. In the aforesaid decision, the Hon'ble Supreme Court has held that the appellant in that case was fully aware of the allegations made against him, and had given an inculpatory statement under Section 108 of the Act regarding the circumstances in which he was arrested with the gold bars. 15. In Sailash Amulakh Jogani v. Union of India, 2009 (241) ELT 348 (Bom) relied on by the learned Counsel for the Department, the goods involved were diamonds, which were not notified under Section 123 of the Act and it was held that in view of the fact that there was no notification, the onus of proving the diamonds are of foreign origin and are smuggled to India was on the Department. It was, however, held that the burden on the Department is very slight and since the diamonds were not covered by vouchers, the circumstance was sufficient to substantiate the case of the Department that those diamonds were smuggled. 16. In Shah Guman Mal v. State of Andhra Pradesh, 1983 (13) ELT 1631 (SC), the Hon'ble Supreme Court has held that the Department cannot press into service the presumption arising from Section 123 of the Act, since there was no seizure made under Section 111 of the Act; which is not applicable in the facts of this case. 17. Per contra, Sri.B.R.Tripathi, the learned Counsel appearing for the respondents, submits that there were no foreign markings on the gold and therefore no presumption, whatsoever, could have been drawn regarding the seized gold being smuggled. The onus on the authority to establish that the articles were smuggled was not discharged and the Tribunal was justified in holding that there was no proof in favour of the Department against the carriers so as to proceed against them. 18. We have considered the decisions relied on by both sides and are of the opinion that in case of seizure of gold, even without markings, the burden is upon the person, who has custody of the gold, under Section 123 of the Act, to prove that the gold was legally acquired. The statement recorded under Section 108 of the Act could be safely relied upon in the proceedings against respondents. In K.I.Pavunny v. Assistant Collector, (1997) 3 SCC 721 the Hon'ble Supreme Court has held that a person summoned under Section 108 of the Act is "not the person accused of an offence" for the purpose of Section 24 of the Evidence Act. The primary question for consideration in that case was whether the retracted confession statement of the appellant is inadmissible in evidence under Section 24 of the Evidence Act. It is observed that even though the customs officers have been invested with many of the powers, which an officer-in-charge of a police station exercises, while investigating a congnizable offence, they do not, thereby become police officers within the meaning of Section 25 of the Evidence Act and so the confessional statement by the accused persons to customs officials would be admissible in evidence against them and it was ultimately held by the Hon'ble Supreme Court that the prosecution has proved the case based on the confession of the appellant given in Ext.P4 under Section 108 of the Evidence Act. 19. The unmarked gold recovered from the possession of two persons and their statements as to the source of the gold was sufficient to have a reasonable belief that the gold is smuggled. The two persons who were carrying the gold had nothing in their possession to prove the legitimacy of the gold they carried. The fact that the gold bars and pieces did not have any marking on them is suspicious and it points to a concerted effort to erase the markings on them. The burden under Section 123 which is only of a reasonable belief; is effectively discharged by the Department who initiated action on the basis of the seizure and the recorded statements of the detained persons. The mere fact that the interception and seizure was not affected in an international border or near an airport or seaport is irrelevant, since the statements of the intercepted persons clearly indicate that they were asked to avoid such means of transport and stick to the normal modes of public transport. There can also be no presumption drawn that the carriers of smuggled gold after the gold reaches the country would only resort to commutation by air or sea. The persons from whom the gold was seized disowned the same and said that they were mere carriers of Om Prakash Khatri, who accepted that the gold seized belonged to his Company. Then the onus to prove that the gold was not smuggled, so as to upset the reasonable belief entertained by the Department shifted and squarely rested on his shoulders. The gold bars and pieces were subjected to chemical examination which revealed that they were of 99.8% purity. The Tribunal ignored this aspect and referred to the purity of the ornaments; which was not an issue before it. 20. There was a Travel Authorisation Voucher, produced subsequently, before the DRI indicating one of the persons detained having been authorised to carry 4002.33 grams of gold, belonging to Penna Gold Impex; but the actual gold seized was 4430.730 grams. An explanation was offered as to the gold seized included gold released from Nagercovil Court out of which certain ornaments were also made. However the quantity of the gold stated to be handed over by the Company and that released from a Court, as initially stated, further changed in the retraction and later asserted in the reply to the show-cause notice, did not tally. In explaining the exact quantity of the gold as available in the voucher it was also admitted that certain vouchers were subsequently prepared with an earlier date. The signature of the carrier in the Voucher also did not tally with that in his statement recorded and the admitted ones in his PAN card, driving license, passport etc. Apart from the fact that the vouchers were not carried with the gold and was not shown to the intercepting officials; there is also no explanation as to how the quantity of gold released from the Nagercovil Court was disclosed in the Voucher, since it was not handed over at Mumbai, where the gold was asserted to have been handed over. The location details of the mobile of the carrier was found to be in Trivandrum when he is said to have visited Mumbai, to receive the gold. There was also no documents filed under the sales tax laws for the inter-state transfer of gold and ornaments. 21. The assertion was that the gold found on the two employees were that purchased by the Company at Mumbai; which details are available in the registers maintained by the Company. The stock of refined gold and gold ornaments as seen from the stock register produced at the time of investigation substantially varied from the abstracts of the stock registers produced before this Court, where Om Prakash Khatri approached for anticipatory bail. The explanation offered for the anomalies was that some gold possessed by sales men were not accounted for. This clearly belies the veracity of the registers produced in the course of investigation. Further the specific statement in the reply was that the gold seized were purchased from 12 authorised bullion dealers in Mumbai. On examination of the records produced, the adjudicating authority found that the gold purchased from these parties were accounted in the stock register for standard gold, while the gold seized was seen to have been released from the stock register for refined gold. However there was no transfer of gold from the stock register for standard gold to that of refined gold. There was also no gold sourced from outside as entered in the stock register for refined gold. This totally demolish the contention of the appellants that the gold seized was that purchased at Mumbai. The registers produced and the transactions alleged did not tally nor did the quantity seized and that seen from the alleged Travel Authorisation Vouchers. The records maintained were vague, incomplete and incorrect justifying the allegation of the Department that they were fabricated. The transactions were shrouded in mystery and were not transparent and exact, especially considering the business of precious metal. The appellants hence clearly failed to discharge the onus of proof cast on them by Section 123. 22. Taking the totality of the evidence analyzed by the Department, as produced by the appellants themselves and the attendant circumstances resulting in the seizure, we find that the Tribunal was not justified in upsetting the findings of the first appellate authority, and therefore, the appeals are allowed, and the impugned order is set aside and the order of the first appellate authority is restored. No order as to costs. Sd/- K.VINOD CHANDRAN JUDGE Sd/- ASHOK MENON dkr JUDGE
summary: The Kerala High Court delivered a judgment on March 1, 2019, regarding a batch of Customs Appeals filed by the Commissioner of Customs, Cochin, against Om Prakash Khatri and others, related to the seizure of gold. The appeals challenged the decision of the CESTAT, which had set aside the confiscation of gold and penalties. The case stemmed from the 2014 seizure of approximately 9.9 kg of unmarked gold and gold ornaments from two employees of M/s Panna Gold Impex Ltd. The High Court focused on the interpretation of Section 123 of the Customs Act, 1962, which deals with the burden of proof. The Court held that since gold is a specified item under Section 123, the onus of proving that the gold was legally acquired and not smuggled falls squarely on the person from whose custody it was seized, or in this case, the company director, Om Prakash Khatri, who accepted ownership. This ruling directly contradicted the Tribunal's finding that the Department had to prove the gold was smuggled. The Court upheld that the initial seizure was justified by a reasonable belief of smuggling, fortified by the fact that the carriers gave inculpatory statements under Section 108 of the Act, admitting the gold was smuggled and that they avoided standard transport methods. Furthermore, the court found the Company's defense unreliable, pointing out that their stock registers and purchase documents were vague, incomplete, and did not tally with the seized quantity. Finding that the respondents failed to discharge the heavy burden of proof cast upon them, the High Court set aside the Tribunal’s order and restored the order of the first appellate authority, confirming the confiscation of the gold and the imposed penalties.

text: INDIA NON JUDICIAL E-Stamp Certificate No.: KA-BLR-ESD-20251028-334455 E-Stamp Date: 28/10/2025 Unique Doc Ref: KA/BLR/2025/10/28/0334455 Purchased By: InnoSense Labs Pvt. Ltd. Document Type: Non-Disclosure Agreement Consideration: Rs. 0/- Stamp Duty Paid: Rs. 200/- Issued By: Stock Holding Corporation of India Ltd. (SHCIL) Place of Issue: Bengaluru, Karnataka NON-DISCLOSURE AGREEMENT This Non-Disclosure Agreement (“Agreement”) is made on this 28th day of October, 2025 and is entered into by and between: InnoSense Labs Pvt. Ltd., a company incorporated under the Companies Act, 2013, having its registered office at No. 88, Electronics City, Phase II, Bengaluru, Karnataka – 560100 (hereinafter referred to as “Party 1”); AND OptiData Analytics LLP, a limited liability partnership registered under the LLP Act, 2008, having its office at Block B, 5th Floor, Cyber Towers, Hitech City, Hyderabad, Telangana – 500081 (hereinafter referred to as “Party 2”). Party 1 and Party 2 are hereinafter collectively referred to as the “Parties” and individually as a “Party”. Wherever the context requires, the Party disclosing confidential information shall be referred to as the “Disclosing Party” and the Party receiving such information shall be referred to as the “Receiving Party”. WHEREAS the Parties intend to evaluate and co-develop an AI-based document classification and summarization prototype (the “Purpose”) and in connection therewith each Party may disclose Confidential Information to the other. NOW THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual covenants contained herein, the Parties agree as follows: “Confidential Information” means all non-public information disclosed by the Disclosing Party to the Receiving Party in any form, including business plans, technical data, prototypes, source code, algorithms, product roadmaps, customer lists, pricing and financial information, and any analyses, summaries or extracts thereof. The Receiving Party shall (a) use Confidential Information solely for the Purpose; (b) restrict disclosure to its employees, consultants or advisors on a need-to-know basis who are bound to maintain confidentiality; and (c) protect Confidential Information with at least the same degree of care it uses to protect its own confidential information but not less than reasonable care. Confidential Information does not include information which (i) is or becomes public through no breach by the Receiving Party; (ii) was lawfully in the Receiving Party’s possession prior to disclosure; (iii) is received from a third party without restriction; or (iv) is independently developed by the Receiving Party without use of the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information. If the Receiving Party is required by law or court order to disclose Confidential Information, it shall promptly notify the Disclosing Party (unless prohibited) and cooperate to seek protective measures. On termination of discussions or on written request, the Receiving Party shall promptly return or destroy all Confidential Information and certify destruction, except one archival copy that may be retained solely for compliance purposes. No licence or transfer of intellectual property is granted by disclosure. All Confidential Information remains the property of the Disclosing Party. The obligations of confidentiality shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of five (5) years from the date of disclosure. This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of India. The courts at Bengaluru, Karnataka shall have exclusive jurisdiction. Any dispute unresolved amicably shall be referred to arbitration under the Indian Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, with the seat of arbitration at Bengaluru and proceedings in English. IN WITNESS WHEREOF the Parties have executed this Agreement on the date first above written. For and on behalf of InnoSense Labs Pvt. Ltd. Signature: _______________________ Name: Mr. Vikram Menon Designation: Chief Executive Officer Date: 28/10/2025 For and on behalf of OptiData Analytics LLP Signature: _______________________ Name: Ms. Priya Rao Designation: Managing Partner Date: 28/10/2025 WITNESSES: Name: Mr. S. Krishnamurthy, Advocate, Bangalore — Signature: ___________________ Name: Ms. Neha Gupta, Head–Legal, OptiData Analytics LLP — Signature: ___________________
summary: This Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA), executed on October 28, 2025, between InnoSense Labs Pvt. Ltd. (Bengaluru) and OptiData Analytics LLP (Hyderabad), is a mutual agreement for the purpose of evaluating and co-developing an AI-based document classification and summarization prototype. The scope of Confidential Information is broad, covering technical data, source code, algorithms, business plans, and financial information, which the Receiving Party must protect with at least reasonable care and use solely for the specified Purpose. The key obligation is the duration of confidentiality, which is set to survive for a substantial five (5) years from the date of disclosure. Upon conclusion of discussions, the Receiving Party must promptly return or destroy all materials, retaining only one copy for compliance purposes. The agreement clarifies that no transfer of intellectual property is granted by the disclosure. The governing law is that of India, with exclusive jurisdiction in the courts of Bengaluru, Karnataka, and any unresolved disputes will be subject to arbitration also seated in Bengaluru.

text: GOVERNMENT OF TELANGANA e-STAMP Certificate No.: IN-TS-01234567890123 Stamp Duty Paid: Rs. 500 Date of Purchase: 18/11/2024 Description of Document: RESIDENTIAL RENTAL AGREEMENT Property Details: H.No. 8-2-XXX, Jubilee Hills, Hyderabad First Party: Mrs. Lakshmi Rao Second Party: Mr. Arjun Verma RENTAL AGREEMENT This RENTAL AGREEMENT is made and executed on this 18th day of November, 2024, at Hyderabad. BETWEEN Mrs. Lakshmi Rao, wife of Mr. Venkat Rao, aged about 55 years, residing at 12, Banjara Hills, Hyderabad 500034, holding PAN No. RSTUV6789L, hereinafter referred to as the "LANDLORD" of the FIRST PART. AND Mr. Arjun Verma, son of Mr. Rajesh Verma, aged about 32 years, residing at 1, Secunderabad, Hyderabad 500003, holding PAN No. WXYZA0123M, hereinafter referred to as the "TENANT" of the SECOND PART. The rent shall be increased by 10% (Ten Percent) for the subsequent 10 months (01 Dec 2025 to 30 Sep 2026), making the new rent Rs. 44,000/- (Rupees Forty-Four Thousand Only) per month. Rent shall be paid on or before the 5th day of every calendar month. SECURITY DEPOSIT: The Tenant shall pay an interest-free refundable Security Deposit of Rs. 80,000/- (Rupees Eighty Thousand Only) to the Landlord. UTILITIES AND OUTGOINGS: Electricity and water charges shall be paid by the Tenant based on consumption. All Property Tax and Society Charges shall be borne by the Landlord. IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties have executed this Agreement on the day, month, and year first above written. WITNESSES: Shiva Prasad Signature: _________________________ Kiran Hegde Signature: _________________________ LANDLORD Signature: _________________________ Name: Mrs. Lakshmi Rao TENANT Signature: _________________________ Name: Mr. Arjun Verma
summary: This Residential Rental Agreement, executed on November 18, 2024, in Hyderabad, establishes a tenancy for H.No. 8-2-XXX, Jubilee Hills, between Mrs. Lakshmi Rao (Landlord) and Mr. Arjun Verma (Tenant) for an initial period of Twenty-Two (22) months, commencing December 1, 2024. The rent is structured with an escalation clause: the rent for the first 12 months is Rs. 40,000/- per month, increasing by 10% to Rs. 44,000/- per month for the subsequent 10 months. A refundable, interest-free Security Deposit of Rs. 80,000/- is required. A six (6) month Lock-in Period is enforced, preventing termination by either party except in case of breach. The Tenant is responsible for paying electricity and water charges based on consumption, while the Landlord bears all Property Tax and Society Charges. Finally, since the term exceeds 11 months, the agreement is required to be registered, with the Landlord covering the stamp duty and the Tenant covering the registration fee.

text: LEAVE AND LICENSE AGREEMENT (Residential Property with Specific Pet Terms) This Agreement is made and entered into at Pune on this 22nd day of October, 2024. BETWEEN Mr. Vihaan Tendulkar, son of Mr. Vijay Tendulkar, aged 50 years, residing at C-301, Koregaon Park, Pune 411001, hereinafter referred to as the “LICENSOR” (Owner) of the ONE PART. AND Ms. Shruti Desai, daughter of Mr. Hemant Desai, aged 30 years, residing at 5, Aundh, Pune 411007, hereinafter referred to as the “LICENSEE” (Occupant) of the OTHER PART. WHEREAS the Licensor is the lawful owner of the residential flat located at Flat No. 104, Blue Skies Apartment, Baner Road, Pune 411045 (hereinafter referred to as the “LICENSED PREMISES”). NOW, IT IS HEREBY MUTUALLY AGREED BY AND BETWEEN THE PARTIES HERETO AS FOLLOWS: LICENSE PERIOD: The License shall be for a period of 11 (Eleven) months, commencing from 01st November 2024 and ending on 30th September 2025. LICENSE FEE: The Licensee shall pay a monthly License Fee of Rs. 28,000/- (Rupees Twenty-Eight Thousand Only). SECURITY DEPOSIT: The Licensee shall pay a refundable Security Deposit of Rs. 75,000/- (Rupees Seventy-Five Thousand Only). PET CLAUSE (ADDENDUM): Permission: The Licensee is permitted to keep One (1) small dog (Breed: Beagle, Name: Max) on the Licensed Premises. No other pets are permitted without the Licensor’s explicit written consent. Pet Deposit: An additional Pet Security Deposit of Rs. 10,000/- (Rupees Ten Thousand Only) (interest-free and refundable) is paid, specifically to cover any damage caused by the pet. Responsibility: The Licensee shall be solely responsible for any damage to the Premises, common areas, or injury to any person caused by the pet, and shall indemnify the Licensor against any claims arising therefrom. Nuisance: The Licensee must ensure the pet does not cause nuisance, excessive noise, or disturbance to other residents. Breach of this clause shall be considered a material breach of this Agreement. TERMINATION: Either party may terminate this Agreement by giving a clear One (1) month prior written notice. LICENSOR Signature: _________________________ Name: Mr. Vihaan Tendulkar LICENSEE Signature: _________________________ Name: Ms. Shruti Desai WITNESSES: Rohan Parekh Meena Iyer
summary: This Leave and License Agreement, executed on October 22, 2024, in Pune, establishes an eleven (11) month residential occupancy for Flat No. 104, Blue Skies Apartment, Baner Road, between Mr. Vihaan Tendulkar (Licensor) and Ms. Shruti Desai (Licensee), commencing November 1, 2024. The Licensee is required to pay a monthly License Fee of Rs. 28,000/- and a total refundable Security Deposit of Rs. 75,000/-. Critically, the agreement includes a specific Pet Clause which grants permission to keep one small dog (Max, a Beagle), with all other pets prohibited. To cover potential damage, an additional, refundable Pet Security Deposit of Rs. 10,000/- is required. The Licensee assumes sole responsibility for any damage or injury caused by the pet and must ensure the pet does not cause nuisance, with a breach of this clause constituting a material breach of the agreement. The tenancy can be terminated by either party upon giving one (1) month prior written notice.

text: DEED OF ABSOLUTE SALE This DEED OF ABSOLUTE SALE is made and executed on this 10th day of June, Two Thousand Twenty-Four BETWEEN Sri Ramesh Iyer, son of Late Govind Iyer, aged about 62 years, holding PAN ABLPI7894F, by Caste Brahmin, by Nationality Indian, residing at No. 22, Saraswathi Street, T. Nagar, Chennai, Tamil Nadu - 600017, hereinafter called the "SELLER" (which expression shall mean and include his legal heirs, successors, successors-in-interest, executors, administrators, legal representatives and assigns) of the ONE PART. AND Sri Manish Sharma, son of Rajesh Sharma, aged about 37 years, by Caste Vaishya, by Nationality Indian, holding PAN DFFPS3221L, residing at Flat No. 404, Lotus Enclave Apartments, Jubilee Hills, Hyderabad, Telangana - 500033, hereinafter called the "PURCHASER" (which expression shall mean and include his legal heirs, successors, successors-in-interest, executors, administrators, legal representatives and assigns) of the OTHER PART. The SELLER and the PURCHASER are hereinafter referred collectively as parties and individually as party. WHEREAS the SELLER is the absolute owner, in possession and enjoyment of the piece and parcel of residential land measuring about 4.25 decimal, lying and situated in R.S. Plot Number 112, corresponding L.R. Plot Number 98, Recorded in R.S. Khatian Number 341 and L.R. Khatian Number 552, at Mouza Velachery, J.L. Number 12, Touzi Number 45, under Police Station Velachery, Registration Sub-District Chennai South, in the district of Chennai, more fully and particularly described in the schedule here under written and hereafter referred to as the "SCHEDULE PROPERTY”. AND WHEREAS the SCHEDULE PROPERTY was the self acquired property of Late Govind Iyer, deceased father of the SELLER and he purchased the same from Sri Ramakrishnan Nair, son of Krishnan Nair of Nungambakkam, Chennai, by virtue of a Sale Deed dated 22nd March, 1987, registered in the office of the Sub-Registrar, Chennai South, in Book 1, Volume No. 897, Pages 112 to 120, Being Number 456/1987 for the Year 1987. AND WHEREAS the said Govind Iyer died in-estate on 10th February, 2004 leaving behind his only son namely, Sri Ramesh Iyer, the SELLER herein, as the only legal heir. AND WHEREAS the SELLER herein, as the only legal heirs of the deceased Govind Iyer, have become the absolute owner of the SCHEDULE PROPERTY since the death of his father Govind Iyer and he has been enjoying the same with absolute right, title and interest since then and he has clear and marketable title to the SCHEDULE PROPERTY. AND WHEREAS the SELLER being in need of funds to meet his personal commitments and family expenses have decided to sell the SCHEDULE PROPERTY and the PURCHASER has agreed to purchase the same. AND WHEREAS the SELLER agreed to sell, convey and transfer the SCHEDULE PROPERTY to the PURCHASER for a total consideration of Rs.85,00,000/- (Rupees Eighty-Five Lakhs only) and the PURCHASER herein agreed to purchase the same for the aforesaid consideration and to that effect the parties entered into an agreement on the 25th May, 2024. NOW THIS DEED OF SALE WITNESSETH: THAT in pursuance of the aforesaid agreement and in consideration of a sum of Rs.85,00,000/- (Rupees Eighty-Five Lakhs only) received by the SELLER through bank transfer and upon receipt of the said entire consideration of Rs.85,00,000/- (Rupees Eighty-Five Lakhs only) (the SELLER doth hereby admit, acknowledge, acquit, release and discharge the PURCHASER from making further payment thereof) the SELLER doth hereby sells, conveys, transfers, and assigns unto and to the use of the PURCHASER the SCHEDULE PROPERTY together with the water ways, easements, advantages and appurtenances, and all estate, rights, title and interest of the SELLER to and upon the SCHEDULE PROPERTY TO HAVE AND TO HOLD the SCHEDULE PROPERTY hereby conveyed unto the PURCHASER absolutely and forever. THAT THE SELLER DOTH HEREBY COVENANT WITH THE PURCHASER AS FOLLOWS: i. That the SCHEDULE PROPERTY shall be quietly and peacefully entered into and held and enjoyed by the PURCHASER without any interference, interruption, or disturbance from the SELLER or any person claiming through or under him. ii. That the SELLER have absolute right, title and full power to sell, convey and transfer unto the PURCHASER by way of absolute sale and that the SELLER have not done anything or knowingly suffered anything whereby their right and power to sell and convey the SCHEDULE PROPERTY to the PURCHASER is diminished. iii. That the property is not subjected to any encumbrances, mortgages, charges, lien, attachments, claim, demand, acquisition proceedings by Government or any kind whatsoever and should thereby and the SELLER shall discharge the same from and out of his own fund and keep the PURCHASER indemnified. iv. That the SELLER hereby declares with the PURCHASER that the SELLER have paid all the taxes, rates and other outgoings due to local bodies, revenue, urban and other authorities in respect of the SCHEDULE PROPERTY up to the date of execution of this sale deed and the PURCHASER shall bear and pay the same hereafter. If any arrears are found due for the earlier period, the same shall be discharged/borne by the SELLER. v. That the SELLER have handed over the vacant possession of the SCHEDULE PROPERTY to the PURCHASER on 10th June, 2024 and delivered the connected original title document in respect of the SCHEDULE PROPERTY hereby conveyed on the date of execution of these presents. vi. That the SELLER will at all times and at the cost of the PURCHASER execute, register or cause to be done, all such acts and deeds for perfecting the title to the PURCHASER in the property hereby sold and conveyed herein. vii. That the SELLER do hereby covenants and assures that the PURCHASER is entitled to have mutation of his name in all public records, local body and also obtain all documents in the name of the PURCHASER and undertakes to execute any deed in this respect. SCHEDULE OF PROPERTY All that piece and parcel of residential land measuring about 4.25 decimal, lying and situated in R.S. Plot Number 112, corresponding L.R. plot Number 98, Recorded in R.S. Khatian Number 341 and L.R. Khatian Number 552, at Mouza Velachery, J.L. Number 12, Touzi Number 45, under Police Station Velachery, Registration Sub-District Chennai South, in the district of Chennai, butted and bounded by: On the North : Property of Mr. Venkatesh On the South : 20 Feet Wide Road On the East : Property of Mr. Ramaswamy On the West : Vacant Plot belonging to Mr. Subramanian IN WITNESS WHEREOF the SELLER and the PURCHASER have set their signatures on the day month and year first above written. SELLER PURCHASER WITNESSES: S. Karthikeyan, 11, Thanikachalam Road, T. Nagar, Chennai – 600017. Priya Menon, 8, Green Avenue, Adyar, Chennai – 600020.
summary: This Deed of Absolute Sale, executed on June 10, 2024, in Chennai, formally transfers a residential land measuring 4.25 decimal at Mouza Velachery, Chennai (the Schedule Property) from Sri Ramesh Iyer (Seller) to Sri Manish Sharma (Purchaser). The Seller, who inherited the property from his deceased father, asserts that he possesses absolute right, title, and clear marketable title to the property. The total Sale Consideration is Rs. 85,00,000/- (Eighty-Five Lakhs Only), which the Seller fully acknowledges having received via bank transfer on the date of execution. Upon receiving the full payment, the Seller absolutely sells, conveys, and transfers the property to the Purchaser forever. The Seller covenants that the property is free from all encumbrances and that he will discharge any discovered arrears of taxes or outgoings from the period prior to the sale. The Seller has handed over the vacant possession and the original title documents to the Purchaser on the date of the deed's execution, and further undertakes to execute any subsequent documents required to perfect the Purchaser's title and enable mutation of the property records.

text: THIS DEED OF SALE is executed at Chennai on this 28th day of October, 2025. BY TAMIL NADU POLICE HOUSING CORPORATION LIMITED, a Company incorporated under the Companies Act 1956, having its Registered Office at No.132, E.V.R. Salai, Kilpauk, Chennai – 600 010, represented by its authorized General Manager (Finance and Administration) Thiru. S. Velmani, M.Com., B.L., FCMA, FCS., vide Board Resolution No.6, dated 09.11.1992, (hereinafter called “THE VENDOR” which expression shall mean and include its successors in interest and assigns). TO AND IN FAVOUR OF Mr. Arjun Narayanan, Son of Mr. R. Narayanan, aged about 34 years, residing at Flat No. 3B, “Rosewood Apartments”, Nungambakkam, Chennai – 600034, (hereinafter called “THE PURCHASER” which expression shall mean and include his heirs, legal representatives, executors, administrators and assigns). WHEREAS the Vendor has sponsored housing and building schemes under the Act for acquiring vacant sites and constructing residential flats. Land alienation – Kancheepuram District, Chengalpattu Taluk, Melakottaiyur Village, Survey No.148/31C, new sub-division 148/33 (part), measuring an extent of 47.60 acres of land classified as Meikkal Poramboke – alienated in favour of Tamil Nadu Police Housing Corporation Ltd., for construction of houses under the “Own Your House Scheme,” vide Revenue Department G.O.Ms.No.110, Dated 29.02.2016. WHEREAS the Purchaser applied via Application No. TNPHC/22/0812 dated 01/05/2025 and deposited ?25,000/- as registration fee. WHEREAS the Vendor allotted Flat No. F-302 in Block C, 3rd Floor at Melakottaiyur Village, Thiruporur Taluk, Kancheepuram District, as detailed in the First Schedule. WHEREAS the total cost of the said flat, including proportionate land share, was fixed at ?25,00,000/- (Rupees Twenty-Five Lakhs only). WHEREAS the Purchaser has paid the entire amount via NEFT (Receipt Nos. 2345–2350, dated 15/05/2025 to 20/05/2025), and the Vendor acknowledges full payment. NOW THIS DEED WITNESSETH: In consideration of the payment of ?25,00,000/- (Rupees Twenty-Five Lakhs only) made by the Purchaser, the Vendor does hereby GRANT, CONVEY, TRANSFER, and ASSIGN the undivided interest in the land and building comprising the said Flat No. F-302, Block C, 3rd Floor, Melakottaiyur Village, Thiruporur Taluk, Kancheepuram District.* FIRST SCHEDULE PROPERTY All that piece and parcel of land and superstructure situated at Melakottaiyur Village, Thiruporur Taluk, Kancheepuram District, Comprised in Survey No.148/31C, New Sub-Division 148/33, measuring to a total extent of 47.60 Acres. Bounded: North: Internal Road and Play Area South: Block D Apartments East: Boundary Wall abutting GST Road West: Common Open Space and Car Parking Area Situated within the Registration District of Chennai South and Sub-Registration District of Guduvanchery. SECOND SCHEDULE PROPERTY Flat No. F-302, Block C, 3rd Floor, “Police Housing Scheme Apartments,” with a plinth area of 1250 Sq.Ft. (including common areas) and undivided land share of 500 Sq.Ft. together with all fixtures, rights, and appurtenances attached thereto. IN WITNESS WHEREOF this deed has been executed by TAMIL NADU POLICE HOUSING CORPORATION LIMITED, represented by its authorized General Manager (Finance & Administration), and Mr. Arjun Narayanan (Purchaser) on this 28th day of October, 2025. VENDOR: (Signed) Thiru. S. Velmani General Manager (Finance & Administration) Tamil Nadu Police Housing Corporation Ltd. PURCHASER: (Signed) Mr. Arjun Narayanan WITNESSES: Mr. K. Rajasekar, 14, Chetpet Main Road, Chennai. Ms. Priya Srinivasan, 6, Gandhi Street, Chromepet, Chennai.
summary: This Deed of Absolute Sale, executed on October 28, 2025, in Chennai, formally records the transfer of a residential apartment from the Tamil Nadu Police Housing Corporation Limited (Vendor) to Mr. Arjun Narayanan (Purchaser) under the "Own Your House Scheme." The subject property is Flat No. F-302, Block C, 3rd Floor, at Melakottaiyur Village, Kancheepuram District, comprising a plinth area of $1250$ Sq.Ft. and an undivided land share of $500$ Sq.Ft., situated on land originally alienated to the Vendor by the Revenue Department in 2016 for housing construction. The total fixed cost of the flat and its proportionate land share was $\text{Rs. 25,00,000/- (Rupees Twenty-Five Lakhs only)}$, which the Vendor fully acknowledges having received from the Purchaser via NEFT. In consideration of this full payment, the Vendor absolutely grants, conveys, transfers, and assigns the entire interest in the land and building to the Purchaser, who now holds the property absolutely, with all rights and appurtenances attached thereto.

text: EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT This EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT (Hereinafter, the “Agreement”) is entered into on this 1st day of November, 2024 (“Effective Date”) BY AND BETWEEN CodeGenius Technologies Private Limited, a private limited company incorporated under the Companies Act, 2013, having CIN U72200KA2020PTC120001 with its registered office at Plot 10, EPIP Zone, Whitefield, Bengaluru - 560066 (hereinafter referred to as the “Company” or “Employer”, which expression shall, unless repugnant to the meaning or context hereof, be deemed to mean and include all permitted successors and assigns) AND Mr. Rohan Varma, son of Mr. Deepak Varma, aged about 27 years, and residing at Flat 302, Green Meadows Apartment, Marathahalli, Bengaluru - 560037 (hereinafter referred to as the "Employee", which expression shall, unless repugnant to the meaning or context hereof, be deemed to mean and include all permitted successors and assigns). The Company and the Employee shall hereinafter be individually referred to as “Party” and collectively referred to as “Parties”. WHEREAS: A. The Company is engaged in the business of Software Development and IT Services (“Business”). B. The Company recognizes that the Employee has the requisite skill set to be employed as a Senior Software Engineer. C. The Parties desire to set forth the terms and conditions governing the Employee's employment with the Company. NOW, THEREFORE, IN CONSIDERATION OF THE MUTUAL COVENANTS AND AGREEMENTS CONTAINED HEREIN, THE PARTIES AGREE AS FOLLOWS: 1. POSITION AND DUTIES 1.1 The Company hereby appoints Mr. Rohan Varma as a Permanent Full-Time Employee in the capacity of Senior Software Engineer, reporting to the Engineering Manager. 1.2 The Employee shall diligently and faithfully perform such duties and responsibilities as are commensurate with the position, as may be assigned by the Company from time to time, including those detailed in the annexed Job Description (Annexure A). 1.3 The Employee's place of employment shall be the Company's registered office in Bengaluru, but the Company reserves the right to transfer the Employee to any of its other offices or locations in India or abroad, subject to applicable law. 2. TERM OF EMPLOYMENT 2.1 The employment of the Employee shall commence from the Effective Date and shall continue for an indefinite term until terminated in accordance with the provisions of Clause 5 of this Agreement. 3. PROBATIONARY PERIOD 3.1 The first Six (6) months of employment shall constitute a probationary period (“Probationary Period”). 3.2 During the Probationary Period, the Employer may, in its absolute discretion, terminate the Employee's employment by giving Fifteen (15) days' written notice or payment in lieu thereof, without assigning any reason. 3.3 Upon satisfactory completion of the Probationary Period, the Employee will be formally confirmed in writing. 4. REMUNERATION AND COMPENSATION 4.1 The Employee shall be paid an annual Cost to Company (CTC) of INR 15,00,000/- (Rupees Fifteen Lakh Only), payable in monthly instalments, subject to all applicable statutory and other deductions. 4.2 The detailed breakup of the CTC, including Basic Pay, Allowances, and Retiral Benefits (PF, Gratuity), is provided in Annexure B (Compensation Structure). 4.3 Annual increments and performance bonuses shall be at the sole discretion of the Company's management and based on performance review. 5. TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT 5.1 Termination by Employer (Post-Confirmation): The Company may terminate this Agreement by giving the Employee Sixty (60) days' prior written notice or payment of two months' Basic Salary in lieu of notice. 5.2 Termination by Employee (Resignation): The Employee may terminate this Agreement by giving the Company Sixty (60) days' prior written notice. The Company reserves the right to waive all or part of the notice period at its sole discretion, in which case the Employee shall not be entitled to compensation in lieu of the waived period. 5.3 Termination for Cause: The Company may terminate this Agreement immediately without notice or payment in lieu thereof upon breach of any material term of this Agreement, or for proven misconduct, fraud, or gross negligence, as determined by the Company in accordance with its policies. 6. LEAVE AND WORKING HOURS 6.1 The Employee shall be entitled to leave as per the Company's official Leave Policy, which currently provides for 12 Casual Leaves, 8 Sick Leaves, and 10 Annual Leaves per calendar year. 6.2 The standard working hours shall be from 9:00 AM to 6:00 PM, Monday to Friday, but the Employee acknowledges that the nature of the Business may require flexible working hours, including working outside of normal hours. 7. CONFIDENTIALITY AND INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY 7.1 The Employee shall not, during or after the termination of employment, disclose any of the Company's confidential information, trade secrets, business methods, or customer lists to any third party. 7.2 All inventions, developments, software, data, or intellectual property created, authored, or reduced to practice by the Employee during the course of employment shall be the sole and exclusive property of the Company. 8. GOVERNING LAW AND JURISDICTION 8.1 This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of India. 8.2 Subject to Clause 8.3, the appropriate courts in Bengaluru shall have exclusive jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim arising out of or in connection with this Agreement. 8.3 Any dispute may, at the option of the Company, be referred to arbitration in accordance with the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, with the seat of arbitration being Bengaluru. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties have executed this Agreement effective as of the date and year first written above. For CodeGenius Technologies Private Limited (Signature of Authorized Signatory) Name: Ms. Aarti Desai Designation: Head Human Resources For Employee (Signature) Name: Rohan Varma Date: 1st November, 2024
summary: This employment agreement, effective November 1, 2024, appoints Mr. Rohan Varma as a Permanent Full-Time Senior Software Engineer at CodeGenius Technologies Private Limited, a software development and IT services company located in Bengaluru, which also holds exclusive jurisdiction over disputes. The contract establishes an indefinite term of employment beginning with a six (6) month probationary period. During this probation, the Company holds the right to terminate employment with only fifteen (15) days' written notice or payment in lieu thereof, without needing to assign a reason. Upon satisfactory confirmation, the employment continues. Mr. Varma's annual Cost to Company (CTC) is set at INR 15,00,000/- (Rupees Fifteen Lakh), payable monthly, which includes retiral benefits like PF and Gratuity. Annual increments and bonuses are stated to be at the Company's sole discretion based on performance review. Post-confirmation, termination by either the Employee or the Employer requires Sixty (60) days' prior written notice. The Company, however, retains the right to terminate immediately for cause, such as misconduct, fraud, or gross negligence, without notice or payment. The Employee's work location is primarily Bengaluru, but the Company reserves the right to transfer the employee anywhere in India or abroad. Furthermore, the agreement includes a strong Intellectual Property clause, stating that all inventions, software, and IP created by the employee during employment shall be the sole and exclusive property of the Company. Disputes are primarily subject to the courts in Bengaluru, though the Company holds the option to refer any dispute to arbitration in Bengaluru.

text: If at any time, any question, dispute or difference whatsoever shall arise between the owner and the contractor, "upon or in relation to or connection with this contractor" either party, may forthwith give to the other notice in writing of the existence of such question, dispute or difference and the same shall be referred to the adjudication of ........ arbitrator. (ii) The arbitration shall be conducted in accordance with the rules and procedure under Indian Arbitration Act, 1940 or any statutory modifications thereof ... ... Clause 74 speaks that the contract shall be in accordance to and "subject to the laws of India" ..... ... Therefore, it is clear that the language in Clause 73 is no longer res integra. It is of very wide. Any question, any dispute or any difference whatsoever arisen between the parties in relation to the contract shall be referable for adjudication by an arbitrator which shall be adjudicated in accordance with the provisions of the predecessor Arbitration Act, 1940 or its successor, under the Act. The laws in force in India including the Contract Act shall apply to the dispute, difference or any question arisen for adjudication before the arbitration tribunal. It would, therefore, be clear that merely because the finding was recorded that the employer did not commit breach of the contract does not per force prevent the claimant to raise dispute of his entitlement to compensation for loss suffered in execution of the contract. In fact, though Section 73 of the Contract Act is not attracted to the facts in this case, Section 70 of the Contract Act stands attracted and be applied to the disputes or difference arisen between the claimant and the employer. The contract was admittedly, extended five times and the work came to be executed and possession thereof was delivered within the extended period of contract. As was found earlier, contract provides for its determination, on breach committed by the claimant, have it executed through other agency and also claim liquidated damages for its breach from the claimant. Rightly the employer did not take recourse to that power. On the other hand, the employer extended the period of contract volitiously in the first instance and later at the request of the claimant. In that behalf it is relevant to read Section 70 of the Contract Act which reads as under : "Where a person lawfully does anything for another person, or delivers anything to him, not intending to do so gratuitiously, and such other person enjoys the benefit thereof, the latter is bound to make compensation to the former in respect of, or to restore, the thing so done or delivered." 71. Section 70 enables a person who lawfully renders service or delivers a thing or does anything not intending to do so gratuitiously, to claim compensation from the person who enjoys the benefit of the services rendered, work done or delivered anything. In equity the person who enjoys the benefit is to compensate the former in respect of the work done, service rendered or thing delivered, even though no express agreement or a contract is proved. In Mulla's Contract Act - Eleventh Edition revised by R.K. Abichandani, Page 754, it is stated thus "Voluntary acceptance of the benefit of the work done or the thing delivered is the foundation of the claim under Section 70. If once the benefit of the work done or thing delivered is accepted, it can be presumed that the said work was done or thing was delivered without any intention to do so gratuitously. Similarly, it can as well be presumed that the person who has accepted the work done or thing delivered has enjoyed the benefit also. Section 70 deals with cases where there is no valid contract.
